Improving Node Representation by Boosting Target-Aware Contrastive Loss

Ying-Chun Lin Purdue UniversityWest LafayetteUSA lin915@purdue.edu Â andÂ  Jennifer Neville Microsoft ResearchRedmondUSA jenneville@microsoft.com
(2018)
Abstract.

Graphs model complex relationships between entities, with nodes and edges capturing intricate connections. Node representation learning involves transforming nodes into low-dimensional embeddings. These embeddings are typically used as features for downstream tasks. Therefore, their quality has a significant impact on task performance. Existing approaches for node representation learning span (semi-)supervised, unsupervised, and self-supervised paradigms. In graph domains, (semi-)supervised learning often only optimizes models based on class labels, neglecting other abundant graph signals, which limits generalization. While self-supervised or unsupervised learning produces representations that better capture underlying graph signals, the usefulness of these captured signals for downstream target tasks can vary. To bridge this gap, we introduce Target-Aware Contrastive Learning (Target-aware CL) which aims to enhance target task performance by maximizing the mutual information between the target task and node representations with a self-supervised learning process. This is achieved through a sampling function, XGBoost Sampler (XGSampler), to sample proper positive examples for the proposed Target-Aware Contrastive Loss (XTCL). By minimizing XTCL, Target-aware CL increases the mutual information between the target task and node representations, such that model generalization is improved. Additionally, XGSampler enhances the interpretability of each signal by showing the weights for sampling the proper positive examples. We show experimentally that XTCL significantly improves the performance on two target tasks: node classification and link prediction tasks, compared to state-of-the-art models. Our code is available on GitHub111Github link will be provided after publication to preserve anonymity..

Graph Neural Network, Contrastive Learning

1. Introduction

A graph is a data structure that represents relationships between entities or elements using nodes and edges. Node representation learning involves converting nodes in a graph into lower-dimensional embeddings. Node embeddings are frequently utilized as features for downstream target tasks. Therefore, the performance of these tasks is greatly influenced by the quality of the learned embeddings. Node representation learning methods are optimized using various loss functions, including (semi-)supervised, unsupervised, or self-supervised. (Semi-)Supervised learning involves accessing ground truth information associated with a downstream task during training. However, when downstream class labels are available, the optimization may overfit to those labels and underutilize other, more abundant graph signals, which can reduce generalization performance.

Unsupervised and self-supervised learning use the underlying patterns or graph structure for optimization. In this case, the node representations are learned to capture graph signals in training. However, the relationship between these graph signals and a downstream target task is not always clear. Optimizing for irrelevant information can negatively impact task performanceÂ (Tschannen etÂ al., 2020), as shown in FigureÂ 3.

While previous studies have demonstrated that self-supervised learning can greatly enhance task performance when they are relevant to the target taskÂ (Suresh etÂ al., 2021b), there has been relatively little work focusing on analyzing the relevance between self-supervised methods and the target task. Therefore, in this work we propose a self-supervised approach, Target-Aware Contrastive Learning (Target-aware CL), which can actively adapt its contrastive loss function based on the target task. Given a pair/set of positive examples and negative examples, the general goal of contrastive loss is to bring positive examples together and negative examples apart from each other. Unlike self-supervised learning, Target-aware CL uses Target-Aware Contrastive Loss (XTCL), which involves strategically selecting the positive examples that enhance the mutual information between the target task and node representations, such that XTCL is relevant to the target task.

However, there are two main challenges for strategically selecting the positive examples that increase the mutual information between the target task and node representations. First, how each node label relates to a target task depends on its local neighborhood, e.g., a local subgraph, and on its node attributes. Instead of proposing a general positive example sampling strategy as in previous studiesÂ (Hagerup etÂ al., 1993), one sampling strategy should be learned for each node. However, itâ€™s inefficient to learn one strategy for each node, especially when the size of the graph is large. Second, the amount of ground truth is usually limited. Itâ€™s even more difficult to learn a sampling strategy for each node if limited ground truth is available.

To tackle these challenges, we develop an XGBoost Sampler (XGSampler) that uses limited ground truth labels in the training data to learn how to sample positive examples that increase the mutual information between the target task and node representations. Our use of XGSampler not only increases the likelihood of sampling nodes to improve the relevance between the target task and node representations, but it also enhances the interpretability of models by indicating the importance of each graph signal for the target task. Our main contributions of this work are as follows:

  • â€¢

    We introduce a novel concept of supervision for representation learning (Target-aware CL), which integrates target-relevant graph signals into self-supervised optimization.

  • â€¢

    We propose Target-Aware Contrastive Loss (XTCL) as an example of Target-aware CL that aims to make the contrastive loss more relevant to a target task. It achieves this by utilizing XGSampler to sample proper positive examples that enhance the mutual information between the target task and node representations.

  • â€¢

    We evaluate XTCLÂ with GNNs empirically, and show that it can reduce generalization error and enhance performance significantly on both node classification and link prediction compared with state-of-the-art models.

Node representation Zğ‘Zitalic_Z learned by minimizing various loss functions can be used for downstream prediction by learning another target-specific model. A target-specific model produces outcomes for a target task by learning a mapping function between Zğ‘Zitalic_Z and the target. For example, a classifier is a target-specific model mapping Zğ‘Zitalic_Z to class labels for nodes.

3. Learning Node Representations with Target-Aware Contrastive Loss

In this section, we will discuss the motivation for Target-Aware Contrastive Learning (Target-aware CL) for node representations and then describe our implementation of Task-aware Contrastive Loss (XTCL) which uses XGSampler for Target-aware CL.

3.1. Target-Aware Contrastive Loss

3.2. Computation Complexity Analysis

Because XGSampler is an additional process for selecting positive examples for Target-aware CL, we have to ensure that the extra cost is reasonable enough. A naive approach for sampling positive nodes via XGBoost for all vâˆˆğ’±ğ‘£ğ’±v\in{\mathcal{V}}italic_v âˆˆ caligraphic_V can be Oâ¢(|â„›|â¢|V|3).ğ‘‚â„›superscriptğ‘‰3O(|{\mathcal{R}}||V|^{3}).italic_O ( | caligraphic_R | | italic_V | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . The number of parallel processes is set to be proportional to the number of nodes, i.e., câ¢|ğ’±|ğ‘ğ’±c|{\mathcal{V}}|italic_c | caligraphic_V | where câˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01c\in[0,1]italic_c âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], the time complexity for XGSampler can be further reduced to Oâ¢(|â„›|â¢|V|â¢BÂ¯/c),ğ‘‚â„›ğ‘‰Â¯ğµğ‘O(|{\mathcal{R}}||V|\overline{B}/c),italic_O ( | caligraphic_R | | italic_V | overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_B end_ARG / italic_c ) , in the graph. According to empirical computational results in AppendixÂ C, we can learn node representations for a graph with half a million edges under a minute.

5. Performance Evaluation

Our proposed model is Target-Aware CL with XGSampler, which we refer to as XTCL. Note that we can optimize any GNN method with XTCL. In this work, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our XTCL with GCNÂ (Kipf and Welling, 2017b) and GATÂ (Velickovic etÂ al., 2018). The dataset descriptions are in TableÂ 3. In our empirical evaluation, we aim to answer:

  • â€¢

    RQ1. Does XTCL improve performance on node classification and link prediction compared to other SOTA methods?

  • â€¢

    RQ2. How supervision signals and training data size impact GNN performance?

  • â€¢

    RQ3. Is it important to make loss function task-aware?

  • â€¢

    RQ4. What semantic relations are important for each target task?

Dataset and Baseline We use widely used datasets to report the results of node classification and link prediction. Cora, CiteSeer and PubMed are citation networksÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2016) and Photo and Computers are product networkÂ (Shchur etÂ al., 2018). If two products are often bought together, there is a link between them. The detailed of dataset statistics are shown in TableÂ 3. For baseline methods, we compare our Target-aware CL with different training signals. DGIÂ (Velickovic etÂ al., 2019), SUGRLÂ (Mo etÂ al., 2022), ASPÂ (Chen and Kou, 2023), and PolyGCLÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2024) are trained with their specified unsupervised or self-supervised signals. Variation of GNN models: GCNÂ (Kipf and Welling, 2017b), GATÂ (Velickovic etÂ al., 2018), DGCNÂ (Cong etÂ al., 2021), MetaPNÂ (Ding etÂ al., 2022), CoCoSÂ (Xie etÂ al., 2022), and SubGraphÂ (Chamberlain etÂ al., 2023) are trained with supervised signals based on their downstream tasks. See AppendixÂ A to learn more about the detailed settings.

5.1. RQ1. Performance on Downstream Tasks

Node Classification
The performance results are shown in TableÂ 1. XTCL(GCN) and XTCL(GAT) are GNNs trained with the proposed XTCL. XGSampler uses the available training labels to learn a model for each uâˆˆğ’±ğ‘¢ğ’±u\in{\mathcal{V}}italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_V, which we use to select positive examples for Target-aware CL. If node representations are generated in XTCL, self-supervised or unsupervised settings, Logistic Regression model is used as the final classifier for label assignment (with learned embeddings as input). We use 10%percent1010\%10 % labels for training and 90%percent9090\%90 % of labels for testing and the reported results are the average of five runs.

TableÂ 1 shows that, with only small number of training labels (10%percent1010\%10 %) to train XGSampler, XTCL(GCN) significantly outperforms most of the state-of-the-art models in both unsupervised and (semi-)supervised settings. (See explanation for PubMed in AppendixÂ D). The overall results in the table demonstrate that minimizing XTCL is similar to maximizing â„â¢(ğ’€;Z)â„ğ’€ğ‘{\mathcal{I}}({\bm{Y}};Z)caligraphic_I ( bold_italic_Y ; italic_Z ) and significantly improve the performance on node classification.

Link Prediction
For link prediction tasks, we compare to similar methods. We remove MetaPN and CoCoS because it is a semi-supervised model for node classification and cannot be adapted for link prediction. We follow the random split strategy used by (Chamberlain etÂ al., 2023). To ensure the training data is limited, we use 60%percent6060\%60 % links for training and 40%percent4040\%40 % of links for testing and report the experiment results, averaged over five runs, in TableÂ 2. The observations from TableÂ 2 is similar to that of TableÂ 1. By training GCN with XTCL, its performance can be improved significantly also for link prediction. This indicates that, by increasing the probability to select proper positive examples for link prediction, Target-aware CL successfully to improve performance over other methods.

This weights also show that the importance of each rğ‘Ÿritalic_r to a target task. The importance weight in FigureÂ 4 is maxâ¡(|wr,0|,|wr,1|)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘Ÿ0subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘Ÿ1\max(|w_{r,0}|,|w_{r,1}|)roman_max ( | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | , | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ) for each relation. The definition of each semantic relation is in SectionÂ 4. FigureÂ 4 demonstrates that different tasks (e.g. node classification vs. link prediction) rely on different semantic relations to determine positive examples, which means one semantic relation which is important to a target task may not be as critical as another target task. FigureÂ 4 also demonstrate that XGSampler improves the interpretability of the learned embeddings, by illustrating which semantic relation is critical for a target task.

6. Related Work

Contrastive Learning have been applied to learning representations for various type of data. The selection of appropriate positive and negative examples is a crucial step in optimizing contrastive loss. In the context of Computer Vision (CV), various image augmentation techniques such as rotation and clipping have been proposed to generate positive examples from the query imageÂ (Le-Khac etÂ al., 2020; Chen etÂ al., 2020). Conversely, in the field of Neural Language Processing (NLP), several pre-trained models are employed to generate positive samples for words or sentences Â (Gao etÂ al., 2021). These data augmentation approaches have demonstrated significant improvements in tasks related to CV and NLP.

Numerous task-aware contrastive objectives have been proposed for word and image representations. The initial work is Supervised Contrastive Learning Â (Khosla etÂ al., 2020), which selects positive and negative examples based on the available labels in the training data. The performance of text Â (Suresh and Ong, 2021; Grover etÂ al., 2022) and image classification tasksÂ (Khosla etÂ al., 2020) has been enhanced through the use of supervised contrastive loss. The SCL depicted in FigureÂ 3 and FigureÂ 2 adopts a similar setting to supervised contrastive learning, and both figures illustrate that the performance is constrained by unlabeled nodes due to the absence of an appropriate method for generating positive samples for those nodes.

Several graph augmentation techniques, e.g. adding/dropping edgesÂ (Suresh etÂ al., 2021b; Sun etÂ al., 2020)or modifying attributesÂ (Velickovic etÂ al., 2019; You etÂ al., 2020), have been proposed. However, these graph augmentation techniques are specifically designed for entire graphs, whereas a single node is more sensitive to local changes made to the graph through these techniques. Consequently, many methods are proposed to sample positive examples based on structural or topological similarity in the graphsÂ (Mo etÂ al., 2022; Dong etÂ al., 2022). However, the relationship between their unsupervised contrastive signals and the objective of a target task remains unclear, which may lead to arbitrary performance deterioration, as demonstrated in TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 2.

7. Conclusion

To ensure that minimizing self-supervised losses is similar to maximizing the mutual information between a target task and node representations, we propose Target-Aware Contrastive Loss with XGBoost Sampler (XTCL). The proposed XGSampler increases the probability of selecting nodes that enhance the mutual information between node representation and a target task as positive examples for contrastive loss. It learns how the target task relates to the semantic relations in the graph and actively adjusts the number of positive examples for each semantic relation. The performance results on both node classification and link prediction have shown that XTCL can significantly outperform the state-of-the-art unsupervised and self-supervised models and significantly outperform supervised models in 90%percent9090\%90 % of our experiments. Additionally, the interpretability of XTCL is enhanced by the weights assigned to each semantic relation. These weights indicate the importance of each semantic relation to a target task.

Appendix A Experiment Setup

All codes and scripts are run in the environment with Intel(R) Xeon(R) Platinum 8358 CPU @ 2.60GHz and NVIDIA A10 GPU. We tuned for best parameter settings using grid search and the parameter settings for our models is in our GitHub repo and the dataset statistics are in TableÂ 3.

To increase the influence of semantic relation r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG on node labels, the label perturbation must happen in a collective manner, e.g. changing the labels of nodes which have high similarity based on the selected semantic relation r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG together. The key lies in that the graph induced by the similarity matrix of r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG should be homophilc to the perturbed nodesÂ (Suresh etÂ al., 2021a; Klicpera etÂ al., 2019; Cong etÂ al., 2021) to enhance the dependency between rğ‘Ÿritalic_r and node labels. We select one semantic relations defined in SectionÂ 4 as the semantic relation to perturb node labels. Our perturbation process is described in AlgorithmÂ 2.

Given one perturbed graph with one train/test split, we train all models based on the training data and evaluate them with test data. The accuracy (ACC) quantifies whether the predicted label for a test node is the same as its label in the test data. The reported accuracy and standard errors are derived from these 15151515 runs.

According to the results in TableÂ 4, the average computational time for learning XGSampler per node is reduced by 84%percent8484\%84 %, compared to Naive XGBoost with time complexity Oâ¢(|â„›|â¢|V|3).ğ‘‚â„›superscriptğ‘‰3O(|{\mathcal{R}}||V|^{3}).italic_O ( | caligraphic_R | | italic_V | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . The total time for learning only increases by an average of 17%percent1717\%17 % when comparing the GCN training time and the preprocessing time for XGSampler. After setting the learning processes in parallel, the computational time to learn XGSampler is linear to number of nodes in a graph.

Appendix D PubMed Performance Discussion

XTCL(GCN) achieves slightly lower performance compared to GCN in PubMed, but we conjecture that this is due to the smaller number of class label values which enables lower generalization error for GCN.

We conducted additional experiments to test this hypothesis in SectionÂ 5.1 We attempted to decrease the number of classes for training and prediction on Cora and observed how the performance varied with the number of classes. The averages of 5 testing runs are as follows:

As the number of classes decreases, the performance of GCN increases accordingly. This is an initial result to test the hypothesis, and a comprehensive investigation is required to confirm it.
